plugins.name: Copy Paste Overrides
plugins.description: A tiny tool that does exactly as described. Useful when working with nested instances. Let's say you have a component that contains a list of items. You are working in an instance of that component and want to switch item 1 with item 2 on the list. You cannot do that because reordering of items is not supported within an instance. But what you can do is just copy and paste the overrides from item 1 to item 2 and vice versa. You're welcome!

119945.release_notes:
You can copy and paste overrides for component properties from one instance onto another.

plugins.name: Figma Frame History
plugins.description:
This tool enables version-controlled frame history management directly on the page. It offers four key commands:


‚Ä¢ Major Version: Select a BASE NODE on the page and execute this command. A NEW NODE will be created right after the BASE NODE, with a version control suffix in its name (e.g., Frame_1.0 ‚Üí Frame_v2.0).


‚Ä¢ Minor Version: Similar to the **Major Version** command, but only the minor version number is incremented by 1 (e.g., Frame_1.0 ‚Üí Frame_v1.1).


‚Ä¢ Unlock History: This command unlocks all previously locked frames in the history, restoring them to their default style.


‚Ä¢ Lock History: This command locks all history frames again, making them transparent.


If the BASE NODE name does not include a version control suffix _${majorVersion}.${minorVersion}, the NEW NODE name will default to ${baseNodeName}_v1.0 when either the Major Version or Minor Version command is executed.

accepted.name: RyanHuang üëÄ
accepted.description:
üî∏ Product Designer
üî∏ Heavy user of Figma
üî∏ Beginner in FE

plugins.tagline: A frame history management tool for creating and organizing frame versions directly on the page

plugins.name: Frontify Template Checker
plugins.description:
This plugin checks your Figma designs and highlights potential issues before uploading them as templates into Frontify. It‚Äôs designed to improve your template creation and management experience ‚Äî making the integration between Figma and Frontify more seamless.


Issues

We‚Äôre continuously refining and expanding the list of checks. This initial release focuses on the most common issues, with more to come. As we improve template import capabilities, some checks may also be retired.


  1. Auto-layout frames
  2. Layers with multiple fills
  3. Frames with image fills
  4. Text case transformations
  5. Image filters
  6. Mixed text styles within a single text element
  7. Unsupported elements
  8. Empty pages
  9. Slice layers
  10. Flip transformations
  11. OpenType features
  12. Hanging punctuation


Support

If you come across issues not currently covered by the plugin, please contact your Customer Success Manager or email us at support@frontify.com.

plugins.description:
Seamlessly Copy Figma Designs to Template Designer


üöÄ Copy layers and frames from Figma directly into Template Designer.

üé® Save time by avoiding manual recreation‚Äîcopy, paste, and edit instantly.

‚ö° Keep your workflow fast and efficient, focusing on design instead of tedious adjustments.

üîÑ Easily update and edit imported layers, plus create unlimited formats.


Perfect for designers who want to work smarter. ‚ú®


How to Use the Plugin

1 Select a frame or layer in Figma and click ‚ÄúCopy‚Äù in the plugin.

2 Open Template Designer and paste with ‚åòV (or Ctrl + V on Windows).

3 Edit, update, and create multiple formats effortlessly!


Features

‚úÖ Save Time & Work Efficiently

Skip the hassle of recreating designs‚Äîcopy from Figma and start building immediately.

‚úÖ Editable Layers

Make changes to text, images, and more within Template Designer.

‚úÖ Unlimited Formats

Create multiple formats from a single design.

‚ö†Ô∏è Keep in Mind

Some advanced Figma styling elements may not be fully supported.


What is Template Designer?

Template Designer is part of Campaign Designer from Cape, a powerful tool for creating templates that generate multiple creatives. Designers can set up dynamic layers, allowing campaign managers to edit text, images and many more elements easily‚Äîmaking creative production faster and more scalable.


FAQ

What can I do with the plugin?

Quickly transfer your Figma designs into Template Designer without losing time on manual recreation.


Can I edit designs after pasting them?

Yes! You can edit imported layers, adjust elements, and create different formats.


Which elements are supported?

Most Figma layers, including text, shapes, and images. Some advanced styling may not be fully compatible.


What if I encounter an issue?

Let us know at Cape Support‚Äîwe‚Äôre happy to help! ‚ö°Ô∏è


This plugin helps designers work faster, update designs easily, and create scalable templates. Try it now and boost your workflow! üöÄ

plugins.name: Avctoris Copyright
plugins.description:
The Avctoris Copyright plugin for Figma is a comprehensive tool designed to help creators protect and manage their intellectual property rights effortlessly. With this plugin, users can seamlessly generate a PDF certificate of their design work directly from their Figma workspace, ensuring that their creations are legally safeguarded.


Key Features:


Automated PDF Generation: Export your design assets into a PDF format for easy documentation and protection.

Intellectual Property Management: Record detailed information about the authors and holders of rights for each creation.

Secure Registration: Easily submit your work for copyright registration and receive a certificate, ensuring your designs are legally protected.

User-Friendly Interface: Intuitive UI integrated into Figma, allowing for a smooth and seamless experience.

Real-Time Collaboration: Continue collaborating on designs while managing copyrights without leaving Figma.
plugins.tagline: Where Ideas Come to Life

plugins.name: VariableMaster - Swap Variables
plugins.description:
VariableMaster - Master all your variable workflows


Variable Master is your complete variable workflow solution for Figma. Switch variables between any libraries - local to published, published to local, or between different files. Whether you're swapping collections within the same file or moving components from one library to another, Variable Master makes it simple and fast.


Features :


- Swap variables between local and published libraries

- Switch collections between local variables

- Switch component variables from library A to library B easily

- Work with current selection, page, or entire file

- See what will change before you apply it

- Handle thousands of variables at once

- Pick which collections to swap or exclude specific variables


How to use :


1. Choose what to update (selection, page, or file) and pick your libraries from the drop down.

2. Select which collections to swap and see the preview.

3. Uncheck variables you don't want to change, then click on swap variables.


Ps : plugin picks libraries only if they are added in the File. You can add them to you file via Asset panel.


RoadMap :


- Find all variables used in your designs

- Export and import variable collections

- Check for design elements that need variables‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã


This Plugin is completely free to use, No charges for swapping variables.
plugins.tagline: Master all your variable workflows

plugins.name: TapTail
plugins.description:
üòå No explicit sign-ups, logins or permissions are required to use TapTail. Just run the plugin!


Have you ever wanted to know if the Figma proto you shared was opened? To see where people clicked? To get insights how your proto works? Read on üëá


Use this example prototype created by Figma to try: https://www.figma.com/community/file/915647337333327091/figma-for-beginners-2020-petma-the-social-media-app-for-pets


TapTail brings real usability data into Figma with minimal effort. Install the plugin, create a prototype sharing link, share the link with your subjects and start collecting metrics. Once you collected enough data (at least one session), you will be able to generate a report directly in your prototype's Figma document (on a separate page).


üí¨ Feedback and questions (I read and reply to every e-mail): laci@taptail.com

‚ô•Ô∏è Found it useful? A 'Like' would mean the world to me! :)


‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî


Tired of bouncing between Figma and external usability test tools? With TapTail, you can see metrics directly in Figma:

  1. Session details: Total time spent, time to first click , count of unique sessions and more.
  2. Click positions: Numbered circles on each frame show exactly where and in what order users tapped.
  3. Interaction density: How many taps landed on each screen, helping you spot hot and cold zones.
  4. Labels: Add a tag when copying links to know which channel drove each test.


Your original designs stay untouched: all results are exported on a separate page and overlaid on separate layers of your designs' clones.


‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî


üõü How to use

A very detailed, step-by-step guide on how to create a sharing link and a report:


Creating a sharing link:

  1. Run the plugin.
  2. Click the blue 'Create' button.
  3. Provide a 'Name' and your Figma prototype's sharing URL (simply copy like you normally would and paste it here) then click the blue 'Create' button at the bottom. Once done, it will show you a list with the created item on top.
  4. Click the item's link icon to copy the TapTail sharing link: it will ask if you'd like to track the link (this is optional but recommended: use only numbers and lowercase, english alphabet letters without spaces).
  5. Click the blue 'Copy link [...]' button. Sharing link is now copied on your clipboard.
  6. Share the link with your test subjects. When they open it in their browser, your prototype will appear like the original Figma prototype (as if you would shared from the figma.com link).


Report generation:

  1. Run the plugin in the same Figma document where the shared prototype is located (this is important ‚ùóÔ∏è).
  2. You can check for new sessions with the 'Refresh' link on the top right corner.
  3. Once you have at least 1 session, you can create a report by pressing the 'Play' button.
  4. A confirmation pop-up will appear first. If you confirm, report generation will start and a loading indicator will appear (normally a report generation takes a few seconds, but could be more depending on your machine's computational capacity and the volume of the collected data).
  5. Report is generated on a new page in the document.


‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî


‚è≥ License & Trial

TapTail is currently in open beta, therefore all features and functions are free for a limited period of time! Feedbacks, questions, bug reports: please and thank you ü§ó


‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî


üîê Data handling & privacy

TapTail does NOT need access to your name, e-mail, files, comments, projects, components or styles to work. It only needs a very limited set of data to function:


Your identity

  1. Your Figma user ID is stored, but only in a scrambled form called a hash. A hash is like a one-way fingerprint: can't turn it back into the real ID. Your ID is needed to assign your account the free license.
  2. Other identity related data is only needed if you buy a license, then at least a billing name, billing address and an e-mail address is required.


Your prototype link

Your Figma prototype sharing URL (copied from Figma, provided by you manually) must be stored so your prototype can be served for your users via the TapTail sharing link (which looks like this: https://ux.taptail.com/s/<handle>). Part of the prototype link is a string called the 'file key' (format: https://www.figma.com/proto/<file key>/‚Ä¶) which identifies your Figma document. Since the prototype sharing URL is stored, the file key is also stored (as part of the URL). Read more about the implications here and here.


Prototype emitted events

List of Figma emitted events that are captured (with timestamp + data such as node ID, click and scroll cooridnates, etc. ‚Äì for more info, click the event name below):

  1. MOUSE_PRESS_OR_RELEASE
  2. PRESENTED_NODE_CHANGED
  3. INITIAL_LOAD
  4. NEW_STATE
  5. REQUEST_CLOSE
  6. LOGIN_SCREEN_SHOWN
  7. PASSWORD_SCREEN_SHOWN


This data is only used to build your in-Figma reports and are never shared with anyone else.

You can learn more about embeds in general here: Embed Figma Files.


‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî


üöß Roadmap & new features

In no particular order, directly from my todo list:

  1. define expiration date+time;
  2. define simple instructions/ welcome screen;
  3. designated success screen (to enable missions);
  4. component variant change handling;
  5. data export in structured form (like JSON, CSV, ‚Ä¶);
  6. <your ideas maybe? get in touch!>


‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî


ü™≥ Found a bug? Got feedback? Have an idea for a feature?

E-mail me at laci@taptail.com!

I read and reply to every e-mail :)


‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî


ü´∂ Credits

  1. The prototype used for demo in the video: https://www.figma.com/community/file/915647337333327091/figma-for-beginners-2020-petma-the-social-media-app-for-pets

  2. Other identity related data is only needed if you buy a license, then at least a billing name, billing address and an e-mail address is required.


Your prototype link

Your Figma prototype sharing URL (copied from Figma, provided by you manually) must be stored so your prototype can be served for your users via the TapTail sharing link (which looks like this: https://ux.taptail.com/s/<handle>). Part of the prototype link is a string called the 'file key' (format: https://www.figma.com/proto/<file key>/‚Ä¶) which identifies your Figma document. Since the prototype sharing URL is stored, the file key is also stored (as part of the URL). Read more about the implications here and here.


Prototype emitted events

List of Figma emitted events that are captured (with timestamp + data such as node ID, click and scroll cooridnates, etc. ‚Äì for more info, click the event name below):

  1. MOUSE_PRESS_OR_RELEASE
  2. PRESENTED_NODE_CHANGED
  3. INITIAL_LOAD
  4. NEW_STATE
  5. REQUEST_CLOSE
  6. LOGIN_SCREEN_SHOWN
  7. PASSWORD_SCREEN_SHOWN


This data is only used to build your in-Figma reports and are never shared with anyone else.

You can learn more about embeds in general here: Embed Figma Files.


‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî


üöß Roadmap & new features

In no particular order, directly from my todo list:

  1. define expiration date+time;
  2. define simple instructions/ welcome screen;
  3. designated success screen (to enable missions);
  4. component variant change handling;
  5. data export in structured form (like JSON, CSV, ‚Ä¶);
  6. <your ideas maybe? get in touch!>


‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî


ü™≥ Found a bug? Got feedback? Have an idea for a feature?

E-mail me at laci@taptail.com!

I read and reply to every e-mail :)

plugins.name: Import large image(s)
plugins.description:
When posting full page screenshots into FigJam, the images would be blurry and unreadable because Figma automatically reduces image sizes when the height or width is over 4096px. Not anymore!


As a workaround, this plugin

  1. slices the original image into multiple images
  2. groups the sliced images together to create one cohesive image


What makes this plugin different from the others?

  1. The ability to import multiple images at once


If you like it, buy me a beer üçª

plugins.name: Variable JSON
plugins.description:
"Variable JSON ‚Äì Seamlessly Export Figma Variables to JSON"


Quickly convert your Figma variables into clean JSON with Variable JSON. Select your Collection, Group, and Mode, generate the JSON, and copy it instantly‚Äîperfect for streamlining design-to-development workflows.


How to Use:

  1. Open Variable JSON: In Figma, go to Plugins > Variable JSON.
  2. Select Variables: Choose the Collection, Group, and Mode (e.g., Light, Dark, or Custom).
  3. Generate JSON: Click "GEN JSON" to create the JSON output based on your selection.
  4. Copy JSON: Click copy button and use it in your projects.


Effortless variable exporting starts here! üöÄ

plugins.name: Find Word Duplicates Ninja
plugins.description:
Find Word Duplicate Ninja is your reliable assistant for quickly spotting and managing duplicate words within your designs.


Key Features:


Duplicate Word Detection:

Instantly find duplicate words across all text layers.


Automatic Highlighting:

Automatically highlights all occurrences of duplicate words for easy identification.


Customizable Settings:

Adjust minimum word length to match your specific project needs.


Seamless Navigation:

Click a duplicate word tag to navigate directly to all its occurrences within your design.


Intuitive User Interface:

Stylish, user-friendly interface with well-designed tags for optimal usability.


Performance Optimized:

Efficiently handles large files without slowing down Figma's performance.


Why Choose Find Word Duplicate Ninja?


Boost Productivity:

Quickly catch duplicate words, save time, and streamline your workflow.


Improve Consistency:

Ensure consistent text throughout your project without any overlooked duplications.


Easy to Use:

Intuitive and straightforward interface suitable for designers of all levels.

plugins.name: Unidup
plugins.description:
Create a design set template that includes component usage and color schemes. With this plugin, you can duplicate your template to a new page, automatically apply new instances of the original component's new variants under consistent layers, and create brand new color schemes.


Additionally, color schemes can be exported in JSON format.



Document Preparation


Document Structure: Prepare the design drafts of the design scheme, which should include "Components Page" and "Template Page", as well as "Color Scheme".


Naming: Each reuse of the design scheme should have a unique name, let's tentatively call it "NAME". This naming is very important as it runs through the entire reuse process.


Template Page: The "Template Page" is the page of your design scheme, and its name should be called NAME. It will play a big role in subsequent work, transforming into various new outputs and serving various new purposes. Therefore, each artboard should contain instances of components for reuse.


Components Page: Each time the design scheme is reused, the output should be unique. The "Components Page" contains unique elements in each set of outputs, and each component should include variants, with the key of the variant being "name" and the value being NAME, to correspond with each set of outputs.


Color Scheme: The naming method for local color schemes in figma is xxx/xxx. When naming, please follow the structure NAME/color1, NAME/color2.



How to Use


Duplicate and Export JSON are two main functions.


Duplicate:

There are three cards in the interface, namely "Components Page", "From Template", and "New Page Naming".


  1. Select your "Components Page", click the "Apply Selected Page" button to the right of "Components Page", and the card will display the details of the "Components Page".
  2. Select your "Template Page", click the "Apply Selected Page" button to the right of "From template", and the card will display the details of the "Template Page".
  3. In the "New Page Naming" card, name your new output.
  4. Click the "Duplicate" button, and you have extended a new output from the "Template Page". Modify the associated components and color scheme, and this output is ready.



Export JSON:

It will list the NAME of all your output schemes, click to export the rgba color values, and download the json to your local.




See usage demo file:

https://www.figma.com/file/jUg3U53QSIzWBEn0RfUdB0/
plugins.tagline: Unidup - An easy way to reuse your design set
